newsitem.title: THAILAND: January CPI confirms easing Thai inflation.
newsitem.headline: January CPI confirms easing Thai inflation.

text.p: The Thai commerce ministry announced a lower-than-expected rise in the January consumer price index on Monday, confirming easing Thai inflation.
The ministry said retail consumer product prices and general cost of living rose 4.3 percent year-on-year in January after a 4.8 percent rise in December and against 7.4 percent a year ago.
It said the January index increased 0.2 percent over December against a 0.1 percent easing in the previous month and 0.5 percent in November over October.
Market analysts earlier expected January prices to rise 4.5-4.6 percent year-on-year and 0.3-0.4 percent month-on-month.
They said although petrol prices fell in the second half of January, Thais normally spent more in the month, especially on food, after annual salary adjustments.
Thai CPI rose 5.8 percent for the whole 1996, unchanged from the previous year.
The ministry said food and beverage prices rose 5.6 percent year-on-year in January with costs of flour products surging 12.7 percent, and meat and poultry prices rising 8.6 percent.

Nuchjarin Kasemsukworarat of Dhana Siam Finance and Securities said the January food price increase was seasonal. "Food prices usually shoot up this time of the year, a few weeks before the Chinese New Year (February 7)," she said.
The ministry said prices in the non-food sector, carrying 40 percent weight in the index, increased a more moderate 3.3 percent year-on-year in January.
Analysts said, however, that the moderating January inflation failed to lift a bearish Thai stock market.
The market has struggled since last week, with the steady weakening of the Thai baht and a strong U.S. dollar triggering a sell-off by foreigners seeking to minimise foreign exchange losses.
The composite SET Index dropped more than four percent to a 53-month low of 754.07 in early Monday afternoon trade before recovering slightly to 761.63 points late in the session.
